messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim, No, I haven t seen any such papers. I imagine in the old days you could get away with that, but most likely someone would raise a stink it they tried
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim,



No, I haven't seen any such papers. I imagine in the old days you could get
away with that, but most likely someone would raise a stink it they tried
that now.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Sunday, January 30, 2005 3:58 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba id



Rich,
I've seen a number of similar "white papers." Mostly they've been for
generic, mediocre later sukashi tsuba where there was really no basis for
attribution to a group. The origami still attests that the piece is a
genuine tsuba, and documents the motif, material, etc. Agreed that it's not
a very satisfying outcome, but for some pieces there isn't anything more to
tell. The alternative would be to just reject the item.

Your guard is more interesting than those generic sukashi tsuba. Saotome
seems possible, but the shinsa team must have seen (or not seen) something
that stopped them from giving that attribution. Maybe they didn't like the
tomoe. If not Saotome it'd probably get a Shoami attribution today.

I don't think I've seen any recent origami with no attribution. Has anyone?

Jim



General dumb question about origami. This tsuba
has an old (1969) NBTHK Kichi origami. I know that
is the lowest; however it says nothing about school,
maker or period. So what's the point of the origami?
Even this great unwashed gaigin geezer would have
eventually figured out it was a tsuba :-) What is
the point of issuing origami that say nothing???

Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: I think it is too early and too rustic to be Toso Miochin, the heads of the tomoe are small in the early style, around 1600 I think with later hitsuana. Alan
messages.messageBody:
I think it is too early and too 'rustic' to be Toso Miochin, the heads of
the tomoe are small in the early style, around 1600 I think with later
hitsuana.
Alan

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: Rich - That melted look to the plate kind of goes with the Saotome call, but notice the tekkogani at the top of the nakago-ana. That old man s moustache
messages.messageBody:
Rich -

That "melted" look to the plate kind of goes with the Saotome call, but notice the tekkogani at the top of the nakago-ana. That "old man's moustache" form makes me think more Tosa Myochin work. Strange the papers do not say something more positive about this, or if they do, I can't read it. (Always liked the "kiku" form of tsuba.)

Ron

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: Darcy, I m not sure about that surface.  It may have had a rough life or it may be the result of artificial aging.  The delaminated blister at the lower right
messages.messageBody:
Darcy,
I'm not sure about that surface. It may have had a rough life or it may be the result of artificial aging. The delaminated blister at the lower right has rather sharp edges.

There are a couple of famous examples of this type with a 5 stupa design preserved in shrines, one of which is Juyo Bunkazai. The execution of this one is more naive. If it's legitimate it would be Muromachi period and would probably be attributed to katchushi. The main point of shinsa would be to find out if it really is legit. Reproduction katchushi and tosho guards were made from at least the Meiji period through the present day.
Jim
Hi Tom and Rich,

Thanks for the opinions... consensus is that it is an old and good piece then?

Iron tsuba make my head spin. She just sent me the scan and asked me to tell her
what it was, and I have no idea so I sent to the list.

If anyone else out there has opinions on age and if it should be submitted to
papers, I would like to know. My friend inherited a collection of tsuba at one
time so these mystery pieces pop up every now and then.

- darcy

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, At least it is someone interpreting the Kaneie style.  The motif is a memento mori as you say.  Sometimes that motif is tied to Sekigahara, but seems
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
At least it is someone interpreting the Kaneie style. The motif is a memento mori as you say. Sometimes that motif is tied to Sekigahara, but seems like it could fit any battle.

Jim
